repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project for Bolivia had a satisfactory outcome
            with moderate risk to development outcome, and moderately
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and borrower. The
            lessons learned were: (1) Bundling of infrastructure
            subprojects can produce catalytic effects. (2) A national
            DRM strategy should respond to the particular needs and
            conditions prevailing in the country in question. (3) DRM
            awareness at community level contributes to ownership and
            sustainability of results. (4) Development of monitoring and
            evaluation systems is critical to accurate assessment of
            results and balanced inference of lessons. (5) The
            importance of the Bank's GFDRR grants in providing
            highly qualified and intensive technical assistance to
            enhance and help build national capacities and
            hazard-monitoring systems. (6) The frequent supervision and
            presence of an on-site team composed of specialists in DRM
            was indispensable to successful implementation and wide
            variety of beneficial outcomes. (7) Institutionalization of
            DRM priorities. Collaboration with the ERDMP contributed to
            FPS' developing a set of guidelines and standards for
            subproject maintenance and repair. This signals ownership of
            DRM concepts and is a positive indicator of sustainability
            of the new or rehabilitated infrastructure. (8) Multiple
            restructurings may create high transaction costs. Multiple
            restructurings may create high transaction costs for small
            operations like the ERDMP and can divert both Government and
            Bank resources away from implementation, especially in a
            context in which inter-agency coordination is already
            difficult. (9) Undertaking a large amount of small-scale
            reconstruction works may not be a viable model in this type
            of context.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Emergency Recovery and Risk
            Management Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Emergency Recovery and Risk Management Project for Bolivia
            is to support the implementation of the National Plan for
            Sustainable Rehabilitation and Reconstruction (PRRES) and
            strengthen the disaster risk management institutional
            capacity at the national level. This is a level two
            restructuring. There are no changes in the Project
            Development Objective (PDO) description or the main results
            framework as the activities to be cancelled have been
            completed by the government and funded by other sources. The
            changes do not affect, alter, or trigger any additional
            safeguard policy. The project was signed on February 11,
            2008, and became effective on December 11, 2008. It has two
            components: first component is strengthening the national
            system for risk management, which has two subcomponents: (a)
            policy development for sustainable reconstruction and (b)
            institutional strengthening; and second component is
            rehabilitation and reconstruction works, which has three
            subcomponents: (a) execution of rehabilitation and
            reconstruction works, (b) accompanying technical supervision
            for the execution of the works, and (c) execution of small
            mitigation and rehabilitation works. This restructuring
            process (extension, reallocation of subcomponent proceeds,
            and closing of activities) will enable the Government of
            Bolivia (GoB) to complete the following activities: (a)
            completion of the Alp coma Watershed Study and Oruro Land
            Planning; (b) strengthening disaster risk management
            capacity; and (c) completion of civil works to reduce
            disaster vulnerability. All of the proposed changes have
            been incorporated into the project operations manual and
            endorsed by the project Executive Committee. The Bank
            provided comments to the operations manual on April 15, 2012
            and it is now waiting for the formal no objection request
            from the GoB.
